Announced
The 1936 "Y" Campaign opened
With the Kick-off Dnner last night
at Levering Hall. Larry Hanawalt,
Chairman of the "Y" Drive, acted as
toastmaster. Among the speakers
Were Norman Heaney, '34, former
editor of the "News-Letter," Edwin
C. Lockard, '31, former President of
0.D.K., and Bill Hammaker, ExecUtive Secretary of the "Y".
The campaign will run until Friday night, with the goal set for $1000.
This year's campaign is strictly a
drive for funds for the maintenance
Of Levering Hall and the "Y", and is
not a membership campaign.
Luncheon will be held each noon
In Levering Hall for the campaign
Workers.

Bowman Describes
Emory Centennial
Hopkins President Spoke On
Education In "The Decisive Hour"
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, back from the
Emory University Centennial celebration, in an invited statement for
the NEWS-LETTER, describes the program and speeches which marked the
occasion. The program, which lasted
all through the week, from Friday,
December 4, was made up of addresses by men of prominence from
both southern and northern universities, and a final convocation and
awarding of honorary degrees on Saturday, December 12.
While in Atlanta, Dr. Bowman was
the guest of Dr. Guy, Professor of
Chemistry and head of the department at Emory. Dr. Guy received his
Ph.D. from Hopkins, and served as
an instructor under Dr. Remsen.
The address by Dr. Bowman was
the opening of a series, dealing with
various topics, and bore the title,
"The Decisive Hour." Its subject was
education. The next evening was devoted to science, when Dr. Cannon
spoke. Following this, law, physics,
and economics were treated on consecutive evenings. Ii' addition to his
address Monday night, Dr. Bowman
attended a dinner in his honor by President Cox of Emory, where he met
heads from a number of Southern
Universities. He states that these
men are especially interested in
Johns Hopkins because of its leadership in Graduate School work, which
originated here, and continue to look
up to it as the leader among the
schools of the South.
On Tuesday evening, Dr. Bowman
attended a dinner with some seventyfive Alumni and their wives, and
spoke to them about the University,
its work, and current problems. He
found them a most devoted group,
keenly interested in the Hopkins, and
active in following its progress. They
hold a meeting each year, on February 22, to hear a speaker selected
and sent to them by the University.
Last year, Dr. Holt, of the Harriet
Lane Hospital, a specialist in pediatrics, spoke to them. The group are

For Levering Hall
There is not a student on the Hopkins
Campus who should not be acutely
aware of the problem which faces the
YMCA each year when it is forced to
appeal to the student body for funds
for the maintenance of Levering Hall.
The number of students who do not
make use of Levering is neglibible;
whether through its cafeteria, its soda
fountain, its lounge, its dancing facilities, the "Y" serves almost every
student in the University in some way
or another.
Undoubtedly the most important of
all the activities in Leverin Hall are
those under the auspices of the "Y"
Itself, and it is these which the student
is most likely to forget or to neglect.
Perhaps the "Y" provides more than
any other single activity for the intellectual stimulation and the encouragement of friendly relations
among the students of the University
in general. The Supper Club, the University Lectures, its frequent open
lectures, its International Relations
Club, and its numerous minor activities would be a boon on any campus
In America.
Every student in the University
should feel it incumbent upon himself
to help the "Y" in its campaign for
the maintenance of Levering. If Levering Hall were ever forced to shut
down, campus life would be almost at
a standstill. To prevent such a contingency every student, whether gradu-

There's a fascinating game whic
was originated on the local campus
We joined in the initial game a
were rewarded with some enlightening information.
For want of a better name the
practice was christened "Thumb-nai
Sketches." To play you need about fiv
people,preferably incluang both sexes
(They can be as intimate as Walli
and the Duke of Windsor or as far
apart as good taste and Hearst). The
name of each is p!aced at the top of
separate pieces of paper and everyon
writes in the most economical descrip
tion possible, quoting from anywher
and anyone, his opinion of himself
Then the sheets are passed around and
hidden from the others, each writes o
all the papers his opinions or "thumb
nail sketches" of the other perso
whose name is on the paper. After thi
is done, the sheets are passed arou
and much to the amusement or chagrin of the players some startling in
formation is revealed.
Then to test the accuracy and honesty of these sketches a chairman is appointed to read them before friends or
acquaintainces, other than the original
group. The reader merely recites th
concise, punchy attributes leaving s
to the newcomer to name the perso
whom the descriptions fit.
If the game is followed in th
proper spirit a great deal of fun a
weql as knowledge (you know who'
kind) can be gained.

campus these days concerning the
Barnstormer's production at the Auditorium Theatre December 13. One
friend of mine who was sitting next
to me making choking noises in his
throat through the whole performance, swears that he was in New
York Saturday night seeing James
Barton in "Tobacco Road!"
'Top Entertainment'
Regardless of its effect on the audience as a whole, however, "Once in
a Lifetime" certainly provided me
with a thrill I've only had once in
my lifetime! The 'Stormers put on
a performance whose memory clicks
words like 'wonderful! delightful! and
'stupendous!' into my mind. I must
say that at its slowest moments (and
the play had very few of those) the
action just about hit the limit in
top entertainment.
Very few of the members in the
cast stand out conspicuously above
the others, because the standard was
so high. Elizabeth Ullman, however,
who played the part of May Daniels,
hardened and cynical ex-vaudeville
actress who breaks into Hollywood
with her School of Elocution and
Voice Culture, deserves in full measure the tumultuous applause she received from the audience. Playing
her part with an easy, perfect familiarity, Miss Ullman put on a sterling
performance that set the pace for the
rest of the cast. The memory of Stanley M. Prager's portrayal of the excitable, mercurial Mr. Glogauer, movie magnate 'in da beezness fer seventeen years!" lingers on and on. Mr.
Prager stands out as running away
With all honors for straight comedy.
In no less degree must credit be
given to Edward Bauernschmidt for
his
characterization
inspired
of
George Lewis, blundering and awkward, whose errors always turn out
to his best advantage in a perfectly
convincing way by the magic and
Skill of the plot of the play. Mr.
Bauernschmidt fitted into his part
like an egg into its shell and left
nothing to be desired.
Praises Miller, I3ranower
Just a little too affected in her first
scenes, Jeanne Miller, playing the
role of Helen Hobart, Hollywood colUmnist, turned in a capable and entirely estimable job of a difficult
assignment. Gerald Branower, as Jerry Hyland, the man who realized
Where Vitaphone was going to lead
the movie industry, is entirely satisfactory and gives ample proof of
the depth of his great acting ability.
Even eclipsing her build-up, Miss
Bunny Harris showed the stuff that
stars are made of in her interpretation of the part of Susan Walker,
beautiful but dumb ingenue, who
breaks into the movies only by virtue of the mistakes of George Lewis.
Martin Levine, hard-working president of the Barnstormers, plays a

On October 15th, the "Y" presented

Dr. Sherwood Eddy and Mr. Sam
Franklin at an extra assembly, with

and Mr. Franklin addressed the "Y"

has supplied student speakers to various young people's groups throughout the city.
Summing up, it may be easily seen
that over 1000 students are partaking in "Y" activities in one form or
another, including the housing of
student activities in the basement
of Levering Hall, and other student
groups meeting in Levering Hall.

HANA WALT

List Of Student Teams And
Workers For Drive
Announced
The 1936 "Y" Campaign opened
With the Kick-off Dnner last night
at Levering Hall. Larry Hanawalt,
Chairman of the "Y" Drive, acted as
toastmaster. Among the speakers
Were Norman Heaney, '34, former
editor of the "News-Letter," Edwin
C. Lockard, '31, former President of
0.D.K., and Bill Hammaker, ExecUtive Secretary of the "Y".
The campaign will run until Friday night, with the goal set for $1000.
This year's campaign is strictly a
drive for funds for the maintenance
Of Levering Hall and the "Y", and is
not a membership campaign.
Luncheon will be held each noon
In Levering Hall for the campaign
Workers.

WILLIAJd HAMMAKER

Bowman Describes
Emory Centennial
Hopkins President Spoke On
Education In "The Decisive Hour"
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, back from the
Emory University Centennial celebration, in an invited statement for
the NEWS-LETTER, describes the program and speeches which marked the
occasion. The program, which lasted
all through the week, from Friday,
December 4, was made up of addresses by men of prominence from
both southern and northern universities, and a final convocation and
awarding of honorary degrees on Saturday, December 12.
While in Atlanta, Dr. Bowman was
the guest of Dr. Guy, Professor of
Chemistry and head of the department at Emory. Dr. Guy received his
Ph.D. from Hopkins, and served as
an instructor under Dr. Remsen.
The address by Dr. Bowman was
the opening of a series, dealing with
various topics, and bore the title,
"The Decisive Hour." Its subject was
education. The next evening was devoted to science, when Dr. Cannon
spoke. Following this, law, physics,
and economics were treated on consecutive evenings. Ii' addition to his
address Monday night, Dr. Bowman
attended a dinner in his honor by President Cox of Emory, where he met
heads from a number of Southern
Universities. He states that these
men are especially interested in
Johns Hopkins because of its leadership in Graduate School work, which
originated here, and continue to look
up to it as the leader among the
schools of the South.
On Tuesday evening, Dr. Bowman
attended a dinner with some seventyfive Alumni and their wives, and
spoke to them about the University,
its work, and current problems. He
found them a most devoted group,
keenly interested in the Hopkins, and
active in following its progress. They

For Levering Hall
There is not a student on the Hopkins
Campus who should not be acutely
aware of the problem which faces the
YMCA each year when it is forced to
appeal to the student body for funds
for the maintenance of Levering Hall.
The number of students who do not
make use of Levering is neglibible;
whether through its cafeteria, its soda
fountain, its lounge, its dancing facilities, the "Y" serves almost every
student in the University in some way
or another.
Undoubtedly the most important of
all the activities in Leverin Hall are
those under the auspices of the "Y"
Itself, and it is these which the student
is most likely to forget or to neglect.
Perhaps the "Y" provides more than
any other single activity for the intellectual stimulation and the encouragement of friendly relations
among the students of the University
in general. The Supper Club, the University Lectures, its frequent open
lectures, its International Relations
Club, and its numerous minor activities would be a boon on any campus
In America.
Every student in the University
should feel it incumbent upon himself
to help the "Y" in its campaign for
the maintenance of Levering. If Levering Hall were ever forced to shut
down, campus life would be almost at
a standstill. To prevent such a contingency every student, whether gradu-

There's a fascinating game whic
was originated on the local campus
We joined in the initial game a
were rewarded with some enlightening information.
For want of a better name the
practice was christened "Thumb-nai
Sketches." To play you need about fiv
people,preferably incluang both sexes
(They can be as intimate as Walli
and the Duke of Windsor or as far
apart as good taste and Hearst). The
name of each is p!aced at the top of
separate pieces of paper and everyon
writes in the most economical descrip
tion possible, quoting from anywher
and anyone, his opinion of himself
Then the sheets are passed around and
hidden from the others, each writes o
all the papers his opinions or "thumb
nail sketches" of the other perso
whose name is on the paper. After thi
is done, the sheets are passed arou
and much to the amusement or chagrin of the players some startling in
formation is revealed.
Then to test the accuracy and honesty of these sketches a chairman is appointed to read them before friends or
acquaintainces, other than the original
group. The reader merely recites th
concise, punchy attributes leaving s
to the newcomer to name the perso
whom the descriptions fit.
If the game is followed in th
proper spirit a great deal of fun a
weql as knowledge (you know who'
kind) can be gained.

campus these days concerning the
Barnstormer's production at the Auditorium Theatre December 13. One
friend of mine who was sitting next
to me making choking noises in his
throat through the whole performance, swears that he was in New
York Saturday night seeing James
Barton in "Tobacco Road!"
'Top Entertainment'
Regardless of its effect on the audience as a whole, however, "Once in
a Lifetime" certainly provided me
with a thrill I've only had once in
my lifetime! The 'Stormers put on
a performance whose memory clicks
words like 'wonderful! delightful! and
'stupendous!' into my mind. I must
say that at its slowest moments (and
the play had very few of those) the
action just about hit the limit in
top entertainment.
Very few of the members in the
cast stand out conspicuously above
the others, because the standard was
so high. Elizabeth Ullman, however,
who played the part of May Daniels,
hardened and cynical ex-vaudeville
actress who breaks into Hollywood
with her School of Elocution and
Voice Culture, deserves in full measure the tumultuous applause she received from the audience. Playing
her part with an easy, perfect familiarity, Miss Ullman put on a sterling
performance that set the pace for the
rest of the cast. The memory of Stanley M. Prager's portrayal of the excitable, mercurial Mr. Glogauer, movie magnate 'in da beezness fer seventeen years!" lingers on and on. Mr.
Prager stands out as running away
With all honors for straight comedy.
In no less degree must credit be
given to Edward Bauernschmidt for
his
characterization
inspired
of
George Lewis, blundering and awkward, whose errors always turn out
to his best advantage in a perfectly
convincing way by the magic and
Skill of the plot of the play. Mr.
Bauernschmidt fitted into his part
like an egg into its shell and left
nothing to be desired.
Praises Miller, I3ranower
Just a little too affected in her first
scenes, Jeanne Miller, playing the
role of Helen Hobart, Hollywood colUmnist, turned in a capable and entirely estimable job of a difficult
assignment. Gerald Branower, as Jerry Hyland, the man who realized
Where Vitaphone was going to lead
the movie industry, is entirely satisfactory and gives ample proof of
the depth of his great acting ability.
Even eclipsing her build-up, Miss
Bunny Harris showed the stuff that
stars are made of in her interpretation of the part of Susan Walker,
beautiful but dumb ingenue, who
breaks into the movies only by virtue of the mistakes of George Lewis.
Martin Levine, hard-working president of the Barnstormers, plays a

Dr. Sherwood Eddy and Mr. Sam

has supplied student speakers to various young people's groups throughout the city.
Summing up, it may be easily seen
that over 1000 students are partaking in "Y" activities in one form or

student activities in the basement
of Levering Hall, and other student
groups meeting in Levering Hall.
